div.p: THE HAPPY FAMILY; A DRAMA, IN FIVE ACTS.
TRANSLATED FROM THE GERMAN OF KOTZEBUE.
New-York: PRINTED FOR C. SMITH AND S. STEPHENS. 1800.

p.hi: The scene lies in a village on the borders of a German principality, and an adjoining wood.

div.head: ACT THE FIRST.

p.hi: SCENE, A room in Welling's house, from which are various doors to a diningroom, a study, his daughters' chambers, &c. On one side is a large closet. The furniture is strong. Taste and elegance every where prevail, unmixed with ostentation, but evidently shewing the owner of the house to be in good circumstances.—Paulina and Rosa are discovered spinning; Frederick and Lewis are engaged in maxing a large net. The clock strikes five.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: FIVE o'clock.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: They'll soon rise, now.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I heard my father cough.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: And I saw my mother throw barley out of the window to the pigeons.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Have you all your presents ready?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Mine is in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Pointing at the table. Mine is under that white cloth.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: And mine is in the court.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Aside, with a sigh. I alone have nothing to offer.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: To Fre. May one ask what it is?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Jocosely. Can you keep a secret?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Oh yes.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: So can I.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Well, I am not so cruel. I have woven some handkerchiefs for my mother; and for my father—guess.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: It will not be worth while.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! do you hear, Lewis? What think you?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: He is probably right.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: How modest! But, Frederick, I'll tell you—Lewis has made some verses for me: they are so sweet and affecting—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I don't understand verses.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Paulina is so kind as to think them tolerable.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Mr. Ernorf makes verses too, but nobody can understand them.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Hark! They are coming.

div.stage: All rise, and stand in anxious suspense.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: No—it was the servant below.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: My father and mother must be very happy to-day.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: That they always are.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Yes; but only consider, they have been married twenty-five years to-day.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: And did you hear what my father said when they went to bed last night? They had not quarrelled, during all that time, for twenty-five minutes.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: He had tears in his eyes when he mentioned it.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My mother pressed his hand, too.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: And looked as affectionate as a bride.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Sighing. It is a singular happiness.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: They are singular people.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: God bless them!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: And soon send me a wife!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Archly. You have made a choice, I think?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Perhaps I have.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: The Forester's daughter?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: She is a good girl.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Brother, I wish you joy.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I wish her father may not have higher views.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Well! who knows what may happen?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Hark! Now they are coming.

div.stage: All again rise and look anxiously around.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh no—It is Mr. Ernorf.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: In a disappointed tone. Only Mr. Ernorf.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: The same. Good morning to you, Mr. Ernorf. How happens it that you are abroad so early?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: The Muses and Graces awoke me.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: The cock awoke us by crowing.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: This is Mr. Welling's wedding-day.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Do you mean that for news?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: The news is to come. As Miss Paulina yesterday signified that she wished to celebrate the happy event by an ode, I have prepared one.

div.stage: Draws a paper from his pocket, and delivers it with self-satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I am much obliged to you, but it is too late.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Too late!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I am already provided with one.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Consequentially. I should like to know where a poet could be found within many miles, who —

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: You need not go so far to find him.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Laughing. Not many steps.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Lewis—

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: With a smile of contempt and derision. This young man?—Ha! ha!—May one be allowed a sight of the attempt?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Here it is.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Muttering as he reads. Happy pair—knows no care—domestic joy—never cloy—very tolerable, if they had a little energy in them. I always say, that when one reads a solemn poem, the breast ought to be contracted, the breath to fail, the eye to start from the head, and every vein to swell.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Heaven forbid!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I like the poetry which inspires gentle sensibility.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Oh, that was the fashion thirty years ago, when your Yoricks used to take their sentimental trips, but in our days nothing will do but hexameters.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: What are those?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: You shall hear directly. To Lewis. Don't be ashamed, young man. Rome was not built in a day. Coughs, and prepares to read.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I thank you, Mr. Ernorf, but if your verses be the best that were ever written, they can't now be of any use to me.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Oh, I beg pardon. Only listen. Scans."Rise with | splendor a | bove the ho | rizon | hot sweating | Phoebus."

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Who is that poor fellow?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Pst!—"Look on thy | humble bard | and smile | from thy e | therial coach-box." |

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Far too high, Mr. Ernorf.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Be patient. We shall soon descend. "Here see a | couple with | love's wrinkles | like | Phi | lemon and | Baucis."|

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Love has no wrinkles.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: I almost believe you mean to criticise, sir.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Apologizing. By no means. I beg pardon.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: There! You can't support the character you assume, for a critic never begs pardon. You will, therefore, do better if you employ yourself in procuring a certificate of your birth. The times are dangerous, and our prince will not harbor any—

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Speak it boldly—vagrants.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Gravely. Enough, Mr. Ernorf.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Exasperated. Too much, I think. He, who is treated by my father as his own son, must be a good man, though he may not be able to write hexameters.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I thank you, dear Paulina.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Your father is not in office as I am. He has not such heavy duties upon him. But—I fear—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: That some investigation must be made.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Into what?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Into the rank, age, name, origin and employment of this young man—this votary of the muses.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Oh Lewis! It would have been better if you had suffered love to be covered with wrinkles.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: He who makes use of his office to revenge a fancied insult—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Is a—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: An under-secretary.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: My father and mother are coming. All rise. The girls collect their presents.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Aside. How provoking! Why could they not sleep another hour?

div.stage: They are immediately surrounded by their children, who call:
div.p: Good morning, dear father! Many more happy years to you, dear mother!

sp.speaker: Wel. and Mrs. W.
sp.p: Thank you—thank you, good-children.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Mother,. I have—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Father, here is—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Stop! I am the oldest.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: In filial affection age has no claim.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Look here, father.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Come to the window, father.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Read this, father.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Children, one after another. What have you there, Rosa?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: A pair of gloves made by myself.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I thank you, my dear girl.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: And here are some handkerchiefs for you, mother, spun and made by myself—and a poem for my father.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Reads it. The sentiments are beautifully expressed. I guess who is the author. Lewis, why do you stand in that corner?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Distressed. I have nothing to give you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A kind word, at least, I hope—a sincere congratulation?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: God sees my heart.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come nearer, then, that I may see it too.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Oh my benefactor! How I wish you could!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I do. Shakes his hand. It is swimming in your eye.—Well, Frederick?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: To the window, father.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why? Goes to it.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Do you see what the man is leading across the court?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A handsome horse.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: You don't remember it?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Don't you recollect, about three years ago, that you admired our neighbor's foal?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I did, and afterwards heard that it was dead.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: That was a deception, for I bought it with my pocket money, and was resolved, when it was in condition, to surprise you agreeably with the sight of it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I thank you, my son.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Dear, good parents, give us your blessing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Your blessing. The children kneel.

sp.speaker: Wel. and Mrs. W.
sp.p: Bending with emotion over them. God bless you!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To Lewis, who wipes his eyes. You too, good Lewis!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Seizes his hand, and eagerly kisses it. Then have I again found a father.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: As long as I live. The children rise.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. Ernorf. Don't take it amiss that I did not welcome you sooner. The heart has its privileges.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: "See, I | come to your | hospita | ble board | congratu | lating."

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: At which I shall be glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: I will have that pleasure. It is a family jubilee; and perhaps—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Father!

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Perhaps, I say—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: All our people are assembled in the court.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Perhaps, I say—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: They want to congratulate you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: They have all made garlands and wreaths.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come then, such wreaths are more valuable than crowns, for affection twined them together.
sp.stage: Exeunt Wel. Mrs. Wel. Fre. Pau. and Lew.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Perhaps, I say — very civil conduct indeed!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: You must make some allowances for the bustle of the day.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: So it seems your fine verses are liked?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: These good people consider my good intention.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: You have been at school, then, as you think yourself capable of writing poetry?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I seldom write poetry.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: In that you are perfectly right, for your muse would not repay the many obligations which this family—

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I often remind myself of those obligations, and should be ashamed if it were necessary for another to do it.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: It certainly was a lucky circumstance for you, that Mr. Welling should just happen to enter the inn, as the recruiting party was going to take you away.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: And that he should be so generous or weak as to pay forty dollars for your discharge.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: You, sir, I suppose, only do this in poetry.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: It is said that poets are, from the nature of their profession, only capable of describing good actions.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Offended. I am much inclined to prove the contrary this very day, by ridding the neighborhood of a conceited fellow.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: In that you would be perfectly right.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: And this conceited fellow is yourself▪ Dixi.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I do not regard your scornful language, for it cannot disgrace me: but I should like to know by what right —

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Enraged. What! I no right! I, under-secretary to his serene highness, own cousin to the cabinet-president's house-keeper—joint editor of a critical journal!—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, what is the cause of all this noise.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Smiling. Mr. under-secretary Ernorf is just demonstrating to me that he has a right to be rude.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I think no one has that right; especially in a stranger's house.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Suddenly assuming a look of friendly complacency. Can I consider this as a stranger's house?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: As far as I know, you may.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Not a word, then, of the confidential connection between us?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Between us!—But yes. We stood as godfather and godmother together, about two years ago.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Oh, that is only a spiritual connection.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: We will let it rest there, then.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: You are joking, fair Paulina; but when I have spoken a serious word to your parents, you will joke no more.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: That I believe.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Who knows what may happen to-day?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: This timid sigh assures me that my happiness is not far distant.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I think, Mr. Ernorf, you should have a wife, who understands hexameters better than I do.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Had I but been allowed to proceed—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: We had but just left our beds— Yawning.—were we so soon again—

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Offended. Miss Paulina is very witty and sarcastic. The melodious lines of this Arcadian swain probably pleased her better.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Most certainly they did.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: But they will probably be the last which he will make in this country.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Well, we can live without verses.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: And without the poet, for he will to-morrow be cited to appear, and if he cannot produce the necessary credentials, will be transported beyond the confines. Dixi.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: He threatens.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: To give satisfaction to his vanity.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: But he may involve you in difficulties. It would be better to declare who you are.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Does Paulina wish to know it?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: It makes no difference to me. I know you are a good man.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Is not that the best title?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: In our house it is.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Your house is my world.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: But should my father be compelled to send you away?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Then I'll go.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: And will you distress us thus by obstinacy?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: You wrong me.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: We are all so fond of you.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Paulina too?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I am indeed, and was before you drew the poor child out of the pond, and—

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I shall then take your good wishes with me into banishment.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Rather stay and be happy with us.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: That I am.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Yet sometimes you seem to forget yourself, and your eyes are full of tears.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I do not complain.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: So much the worse, for, if you did, one might relieve you.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Alas, no.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: But at least console you.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Have you then no hope on earth?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Seriously. Lewis—you have not committed any crime?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Lays his hand on his breast. That have I not.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: None but the guilty can be quite devoid of hope.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: That is a pious falshood.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: A good man every where inspires confidence.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I have found it.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: And friendship—

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Sustains my life.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: With timid uncertainty. And love—

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Alas! love I must renounce.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Poor, without a name—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Who falls in love with names?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Without parents, without—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Any more?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Perhaps I have too long remained in a house, where captivating innocence, united with sisterly affection have deceived my heart with lovely visions—where the danger of appearing ungrateful increases every hour, and the pleasure of daily beholding Paulina may at last rob me of my only treasure—a good conscience.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p:
What does he mean?—Is it a sin to love me?—When there was a great fire in our village, and he carried the old man on his back through the flames, did not my father himself allow him to call me sister? "Love him as
your brother," he said to us all, "for he deserves it." I have loved him as my brother, and what is the consequence? Mysterious man!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Away, sister!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: My father and mother are coming.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Why should I run away from them?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I have been talking to my mother, about my dear Louisa, and she is going to mention it to my father.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I wish you success, brother.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: And Mr. Dalner will soon be here too.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Hark! They are coming.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Go, then, and tell Rosa not to disturb them, while I run to the dove-cot, and watch when Mr. Dalner comes.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Now will he be so violent that he'll spoil a nest or two. The poor pigeons! Sighing. Poor Paulina!

div.stage: Enter WELLING and Mrs. WELLING, arm in arm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I hope you approve of my having sent to invite my poor relations.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Approve! I do indeed, and am angry with myself that it did not occur to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: The good people come so seldom, and are so reserved on account of their poverty.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: For that reason we must give them a more hearty welcome, that they may not reckon us among the creatures, who find delight in ostentatiously exhibiting their wealth to poor relations, and making every morsel nauseous by humiliating arrogance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I may place my old uncle at the top of the table—may I not?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Mr. Dalner won't be offended?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Not he—nor Rehberg.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Oh, I am not afraid of his being so; for he had rather himself belong to the family.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Have not you perceived that he is fond of Rosa?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The mother is always quicker in discoveries of this kind than the father, but I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Yet I don't altogether like it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why not? Rehberg is a worthy young man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: The world says a great deal against him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Scandal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: It is said that he does not strictly conform to the orthodox belief.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: His conduct is upright, and I have often before remarked, that calumny does not attack a man's opinions till his conduct is found to be irreproachable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: His intercourse with the Secretary's daughters appears to many of a suspicious nature.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Because many feel what many would do in Rehberg's situation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: It is said, too, that he squanders his small fortune away at cards, when at the Secretary's house.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Ann, you know I hate that term, "It is said," when an honest man's character is concerned. Is he in debt?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Not exactly that, but he had a good library, which he lately sold for a trifle to an antiquarian, who was passing through the place.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What is that to us?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I am sorry for it. The school-master says that when the man took the books away, Rehberg looked out of the window after him, and tears stood in his eyes.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Pshaw! If you will give the school-master a pint of beer, and his wife a cup of coffee, you may hear a hundred such stories. I cannot bear that any one's good name should be destroyed to afford conversation at a tea-table, that the gosling should catch it from the goose, and learn to hiss at every one, who is quietly passing by.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Surveying him calmly and affectionately. I know this censure was not intended for me.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Gives her his hand. Heaven forbid! You are a good woman, and I dare be sworn you will receive Rehberg kindly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: That I will.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I would willingly see none but smiling countenances to-day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Then I fear Frederick must not come to table.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: He has something on his mind.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nothing wrong, I hope?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Oh no—he thinks of marrying.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: If his choice be proper—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And the girl likes him—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: She does—but her rank is rather above his—Dalner's daughter.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: H-m—with all my heart—if the father will give his consent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: There lies the difficulty. He shook his head.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He is a sensible man, and my friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: He is coming hither to converse with you on the subject.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am glad of it. Such men as he and I shall soon understand each other.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: May I give Frederick any encouragement? I see the poor fellow's stationed at the door.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Turns round. Frederick, what are you doing there? Do you avoid your father?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Father, Mr. Dalner will be here directly.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Are you afraid of him?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I don't know. I am not timorous in general; but for several weeks I have felt all day, as if there was a storm in the air, and all night as if a fire would break out in the village.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Smiling. Yes, yes.—But are you thoroughly convinced that you will be happy with the girl?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Strikes his breast with both hands. I am indeed.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: As happy as your parents?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: We love each other as sincerely as they do.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: We are not speaking of days but years.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: So will I by God's assistance, speak to my son in five and twenty years.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: 'Tis well. Go with your mother, while I speak to Dalner.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Kisses his hand in great emotion. Father—yes, father—you must speak—for I—I can't speak.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Alone. Yes. From my heart I wish to bind him to his present rank in life for ever. A good wife will complete what habit and education have founded.—Then I shall die in peace, and he may pry into the secrets of yon closet. What he finds there will not cause him a sleepless night.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Joy be with you neighbor! Your hand! Shakes it. Understood?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: It is the congratulation of an honest man.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Right, by my soul. It comes from the heart. I walked hither, and stumbled so often that I nearly broke my neck two or three times, for I was calling to mind those happy days, when my Maria was alive, and we so often used to spend our Sundays together like good neighbors—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Talking of peace and war—

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: While our wives talked of pies and puddings—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And our children were playing round us.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Then we used to wander to the tall oak. Neighbor, when I passed that oak to-day, I felt an odd sensation. I could see the church-yard from it—Understood? The trees which I planted there—you know where—are grown large and handsome. I saw them peering above the wall, and my eyes—Understood?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You would have been married almost as long as myself.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: True.—When I espied your house, I was well again. It is the house, thought I, of a man, whom I have known for twenty-seven years. I have two things on which I can still rely—my gun and my friend Welling.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Kindly offers his hand. Your sincere friend, Welling.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Well, we may perhaps be united still closer, if we do as two young people seem to wish. Understood?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Almost.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Your son has taken a liking to my daughter, and she by no means seems cruel.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: So much the better.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Perhaps it may be so, but allow me, neighbor, to ask what your intentions are respecting the young man.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He is my only son, and my heir.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: What do you mean to make of him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A countryman, like his father.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: To that I have no objection. Heaven bless all honest countrymen! They are the trees, and all other people the caterpillars, who feast upon their leaves.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: 'Tis well. If such be your sentiments—

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Such are my sentiments, but I have still to ask another question. Were we not old friends I should be ashamed of doing it—but you know me. You know I never was tormented by that demon—pride. We have lived on the terms of brothers. I have never asked where you came from, who you are, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I have often felt the obligation you conferred upon me by this silence.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
Nor should I have ever said a word on that subject, had not this affair of the children—understand me properly, neighbor—not that I have any scruples. No. An honest man is a nobleman. But I have two brothers who are as proud as Lucifer. They are both rich, and my daughter
will inherit their property—nota bene, if she marries with their consent.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Poor Frederick!

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Why so? You are rich and that goes a great way. But one stone lies in the way—your origin. With sincere good humor. Don't be offended.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: People are fond of talking, and some account of you has reached the ears of my brothers. When you arrived here twenty-seven years ago, and your late father-in-law farmer Wiedeman treated you so kindly, it was said you were a foundling, and when the magistracy insisted on your producing a certificate of your birth—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I appealed to the Prince in person.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Very true. And as the secretary here dropped the subject, nay was afterwards seen to take off his hat as he passed you, it was rumored that he had received orders from court not to molest you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He probably had.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: The wise folks then maintained, that you were certainly the natural son of some distinguished personage.—Understood?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Perfectly.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: One of my brothers was then tutor to the pages at court, and stated that your audience with the Prince exceeded an hour.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: It did.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: The world, therefore, not knowing what to make of the matter—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Made something bad of it. That is natural.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: But you see if I could retain the family property for my daughter—but without a mean action—Understood?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Certainly, you would be glad to do it.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: You would therefore oblige me, if you would entrust me with a few particulars of your descent.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My dear friend, I will do it with pleasure, for I am sure you will not make a bad use of my confidence. The time too, when this discovery might be attended with danger, is past, for my enemies have forgotten me.—I am, by birth, a nobleman—

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: A nobleman!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The last branch of the old house of Wellingrode. I was fortunate enough in my youth to become the favorite of a Prince, and unfortunate enough to have none but honest intentions towards him.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: I understand. You wanted to introduce truth at court.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The intrigues of an ambitious woman (who wished to raise her husband to the rank of prime-minister in order to govern through him) hurled me from my eminence. I was accused of treason, my property was confiscated and bestowed upon the new favorite. I escaped imprisonment by flight. How I was pursued and what I endured I will relate at another time. At present I will merely confine myself to the lucky turn of my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Right—how you were metamorphosed from a nobleman into a peasant?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My late father-in-law had rented a farm on my mother's estate, and I had always heard him mentioned as an upright man.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: He was one.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: No longer knowing where I could be secure from the spies of my victorious rival, I suddenly remembered this old faithful servant. I clothed myself as a peasant, cut my hair, and on a summer's evening arrived at the house of Hans Wiedeman.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: I'll bet a wager you were received with open arms.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
Gently rest the ashes of that worthy man!—At first I merely meant to stay with him till the storm was blown over, and I forgotten. That I might not, in the mean time, be without employment, I began to cultivate a part of the
garden. My Ann was then but fourteen years of age, and assisted me.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Yes, yes—I understand.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You are mistaken. Much as I admired her, I little thought that we should celebrate a day like this. But the garden soon became too confined for me, and I began to accompany good Wiedeman to the field. I acquired a love of agriculture. I daily felt fresh air and industry enliven both my body and the mind. I was healthier than before, and I was happier than before.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: I can easily conceive it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: One evening, as I was walking alone across the meadows, the idea suddenly struck me—Oh I could shew you the very spot—to forget the distressing vision of my younger days, to renounce the airy phantoms of ambition, and become a quiet peasant.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: What thought honest old Wiedeman to this?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He shook his head.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: I should have done so, too.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He thought my intention a mere whim, and that, when the times altered, I should repent my resolution. In vain did I represent to him that he was old, that he wanted a hale son-in-law—

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: He shook his head again, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He smiled, wished to convince me I was wrong, and when he found his arguments were ineffectual, he said he would try my resolution for two years. Finding, after the expiration of them, that I thought no more of court, and that his daughter sincerely loved me, he said: "God bless you!"—and God has blessed us.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: H-m! — Do your children know—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: But your wife—?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nor she. Her father carried the secret with him to the grave. She is happy in her present situation.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Well, I will say no more to my brothers than is absolutely necessary—Understood? But—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Another But!

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: You injure your son by this connexion.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: My daughter has no ancestors.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And my son is a farmer.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Well, then—if you be so inclined—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am from my heart.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Let me embrace you, then.—I may call you, as hitherto friend and neighbor?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Most certainly.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: If my good Maria had lived to see this day—or if those above know what passes here below—Understood?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I can restrain him no longer.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: With eager anxiety. Well, Father! You look kind—so does Mr. Dalner.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: We are agreed.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Huzza!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Frederick, where are you going?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: To Louisa.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Hold! Has your mother consented?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: If you have no objection—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Objection! It makes me shed tears of joy.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Now I may—

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Stop! Such intelligence as this ought to be conveyed by the father.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: But I may go with you.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Go you may, but instead of going you'll run, and I am not in a hurry to provoke the asthma. No, be patient till evening—then I'll bring my daughter hither. Till then, good bye, neighbors.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Following him. Afternoon, instead of evening.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: He is in love indeed!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He will be so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: He is so.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Impossible, for real love never exists till after marriage. The passion of the youth is only smoke—but the husband's affection is the pure flame, with which he is warmed even in old age.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: As is our case.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes, good Ann, as is our case. In spite of all our Frederick's warmth, I dare be sworn that I shall be, when sixty years of age, still more in love than he.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Smiling. You in love! With whom?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Can you ask? Affectionately giving his hand. With you, who have for a quarter of a century been my faithful companion—with you, who have so cheerfully, so excellently adhered to the duties of a wife and mother.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I have but done my duty.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And always did it cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: God has rewarded me.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: God bless you! Come into my arms!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Good William!

div.stage: Wel. presses her with emotion in his arms.

div.head: ACT THE SECOND.
div.stage: Enter Ernorf, in full dress. His pockets are full of papers. He surveys himself in the glass, and arranges his cravat.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p:
Now she may decide. If she likes the under-secretary, the man of business— Laying his hand on his right coat-pocket.
here he is. If she likes the poet, the author— Pointing to his left coat-pocket. here he is. The right pocket will suit the father and mother—the left the daughters—both will, I think, overpower the Arcadian shepherd, Mr. Lewis.—To-day will I bestow this hand, which has written so many a folio—so many a quarto, on — Paulina or Rosa? Immaterial.—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Come in, sir—we are all happy.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: It is your father's wedding-day.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Oh yes, but other weddings will soon take place.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Aside. Yes, yes, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: You shall perform the ceremony—

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: For whom?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Jocosely. Guess.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Perhaps Miss Paulina.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Aside. Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: You are wrong.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: In great agitation. Or perhaps Miss Rosa?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Aside. Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Wrong again.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Recovering. Then I know nobody—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: How! Am I nobody?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: You yourself, dear Frederick?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Yes, I myself, and somebody else too—Louisa Dalner—eh?—What say you now?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I am really glad to hear it, and as all the family is so happy, I cannot suppose that Miss Rosa will attend to her harpsichord to-day.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I don't know, but I'll call her.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Happy man!

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Under the rose, Mr. Rehberg, you will, ere long, have to read the marriage-ceremony for one of his sisters.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Which?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: That is not yet determined. Cupid gropes in the dark, as at the rape of the Sabines.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Perhaps you yourself are Cupid.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: With self-satisfaction. At your service.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: You are about to marry, then?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Prosaically answered: Yes.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Marry without affection!

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Who said that? I love—I burn!

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Yet you said you had not made a choice.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: My heart certainly inclines rather towards Paulina—

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Obey the impulse, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: But she wants taste. Her sister is, I think, in many respects superior—and she has so poetical a name—Rosa!

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: — You have spoken to Mr. Welling, I presume?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Not yet. He is a good honest kind of man.—But— Looking at his watch. it grows late, and I must attend to the duties of my office.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: This fellow is a silly coxcomb—but can I, for that reason, feel at ease? He is rich, and oh, how many fools, how many villains have I known, who have obtained the most amiable wives, because they were rich! I have hitherto been silent, but my intentions are upright—why, therefore, should I be ashamed of declaring them?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. Rehberg, I was almost afraid you would come.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Afraid!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Because I have been idle. Look, only, what a quantity of dust there is upon the harpsichord.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: That is indeed unusual.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I have been making a present for my father and mother, on their wedding-day—

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: You have, then, certainly been far better employed than in attending to music.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Yet I have often been singing; for when I am alone I always sing—and you know my favorite words:
sp.l: " Why, fate, dost thou thine ear thus shut,

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.l: " All I require is but a hut,
" And friend, and little humble flock.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: " Blest with such gifts, I still should know▪
" Peace and contentment felt by few—

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.l: " Yet how much more my breast would glow,
" If I might share those joys with you."

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: You repeat the last lines as if you were the author of them.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: How if I were?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Jocosely. Why, then I would ask who it is for whom your breast would glow?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: And I would answer, a cheerful, good, pretty girl.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Do I know her?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Perhaps you do.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: She must live in our village, then, for I have scarcely been half a mile from it.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Will you say a good word for me?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Why don't you speak to her yourself?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I am afraid of displeasing her.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Well, that is odd. Mr. Ernorf, whom nobody likes, torments every girl in the village with his nonsense, and you, whom we all like—

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Mr. Ernorf is rich—I am poor.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: But a good man without a dollar is preferable to him and all his riches.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Poverty is oppressive.—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Without affection it is.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Are you in earnest, dear Rosa? Would a good man's poverty not deter you from marrying him?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: If I liked him, certainly not.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: You are accustomed to affluence.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: There you are mistaken. My father is, to be sure, reckoned rich—

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: He certainly is rich.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Then he has acted very properly in not letting us discover it. We are as industrious and economical as any peasant's family in the village.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: What you say makes me truly happy.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Indeed! Why so?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Because it seems not so difficult to gain your affections as I supposed.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Does any one wish to gain them?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.l: " Blest with such gifts I still should know
" Peace and contentment felt by few,
" Yet how much more my breast would glow,
" Might I but share the joys with you."

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Confused. What do you mean—am I the You?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Ask your heart.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My heart is a flatterer.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Will you share my fate?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Does that depend on me?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Will you make me happy?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Can I?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: A poor mother is my only property.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I should then have two good mothers.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I live in a small hut.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Content is not a friend of palaces.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I live on scanty fare.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: And are healthy with it.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: May I speak to your father?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: With downcast eyes. My mother must know it, too.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: And if they both consent—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I must obey.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Must!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I will most cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Thanks, good Rosa, you shall not repent it.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Much confused. Shall we go to the harpsichord?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: You would learn nothing of me to-day.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I'll fetch my notes. Runs away to conceal her confusion.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Sweet lovely being! What a friendly look will every thing assume, when you come to inhabit my hut? The coughing old servant will no longer awake me, but Rosa's simple song.—And my mother—my good mother!—On her too I shall bestow comfort in her latter days.—Oh God! bend the hearts of the parents, that when they find I am honest, they may not ask whether I am rich.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Welcome, Mr. Rehberg. I thank you for your well-meant congratulation.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: It is indeed well-meant, though you have not allowed me time to offer it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sincerity is sparing in words. I hope, therefore, you will be silent, and celebrate this happy day by drinking a glass of wine with me.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: With great pleasure.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You must play us a good tune—Rosa shall sing, and we will join in chorus. We will pass the bottle round to the health of every honest man, with a wish that after days of toil he may enjoy such happiness as ours.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Alas, Mr. Welling! Such happiness is seldom found.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: True, and most seldom among those who are bred to a profession. You waste your best years in study, and are often at last obliged to be satisfied with a single dish upon your table.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: But the professional man can also feel the charms of love, and sometimes find a girl, who is willing to share his poverty.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Oh yes, but the girl is, with your permission, a very silly one.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Starts. Such sentiments astonish me from your lips.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Love is a pretty flower, but it must grow in the shade of a fruitful tree.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: You think, then, that riches only can make the married state happy.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Heaven forbid that I should have such an idea! There is a pleasant easy track, between the high-road of wealth and the thorny path of penury. I only mean that a man who marries with no other prospect than care and poverty is either very unwise—or very much in love.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Aside. Oh misery! Aloud. You would, therefore, not bestow your daughters upon any but men of tolerable means?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I think, at least, that no man of honor would wish to be supported entirely by his wife's means.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Checking his sensibility. Such a declaration would silence any one.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Have I at last found you, worthy Mr. Welling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Mr. Ernorf wishes to have some conversation with you.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Wishes to unburden his over-loaded heart.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How happens it that your heart is over-loaded?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Through the sly manoeuvres of the little god, who tames the lion—through a wanton frolic of the little urchin, who put into the hands of Hercules the distaff of fair Deianira.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Mr. Ernorf, your mode of explaining is original, but unintelligible.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I will assist him, sir. He is in love.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: With one of my daughters?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Laughing. With both.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Shaking her head. With both?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Yes. This is a privilege which belongs exclusively to us poets. We may be in love with two or three women at the same time.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And you wish to marry both?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: My wishes are more limited. If either of the ladies—

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: My presence may be unpleasant. Allow me to withdraw.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: With a degree of sensibility but without asperity. To make room for a man of property.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Aside. So, so!—Understood, as my friend Dalner would say.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Calling after him. Stay! Stay! We shall want a black coat at the wedding.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Are matters advanced so far?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: They very soon will be. In the first place it is proper that I should ascertain my pedigree. Presents a large scroll. Here is the testimonial of my matriculations at the university. Here his highness's appointment of me to my present office.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: We read that in the newspapers.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Here are some bonds, and—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Enough, enough, Mr. Ernorf!

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Yes, enough indeed. I flatter myself there are few sons-in-law, who could produce so much.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The choice of my daughters depends upon their hearts.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Is it to Paulina or to Rosa that your intentions are directed?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: That I leave entirely to the decision of the lovely creatures, themselves.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: 'Tis well. Here come the lovely creatures. Talk to them, yourself; for if I know their dispositions, I may quietly remain a silent spectator.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Children, Mr. Ernorf wishes to marry one of you.

sp.speaker: Pau. and Ros.
sp.p: Make low curtsies. He does us great honor.
sp.stage: Ernorf returns their compliments by two low bows.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He thinks you both so amiable, that he finds it impossible to make a choice.

sp.speaker: Pau. and Ros.
sp.p: As above. He does us great honor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: And leaves you, therefore, to decide.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My sister is the oldest, and has a right to the preference.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: But Rosa excels me in accomplishments.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Such modesty deserves to be rewarded.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: It is only your modesty, which makes you not feel superior to me.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! What a noble contest!—I perceive I must advance to the aid of their reserve.— Solemnly. Accept, beauteous Paulina, a heart, which—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Mr. Ernorf, but I accept no present, which I cannot return.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Somewhat confused, but suppressing his mortification. Indeed!—Well then, do accept it, fair Rosa—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Indeed, Mr. Ernorf, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: What!—How!—Both!—How am I to understand this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: My daughters are grateful for the honor you wish to confer upon them.

sp.speaker: Pau. and Ros.
sp.p: Curtsying. Yes, we are grateful for the honor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: But do not as yet feel inclined to marry.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Whose mortification begins to appear, and soon after increases to rage. Such may be your opinion, Mrs. Welling, but you are much mistaken. The ladies had rather be married to-day than to-morrow—yes, rather to-day than to-morrow, I say.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: The girls are in love—yes, they are in love, I say.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: You seem to be an interpreter of hearts.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: And a certain stripling in this house, a shallow poetaster is a conqueror of hearts.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Seriously. What do you mean, sir?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: A fellow, of whom we know no more than we do of the wind, where he comes from, or is going to?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Emphatically. Mr. Ernorf, I request an explanation.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p:
You shall have it. I came here to make an explanation. The dapper spark, Lewis, whose release you thought
proper to buy of a recruiting party, has in return enlisted your daughters.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Mr. Ernorf, my daughters are virtuous women.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Virtuous they may be; but they are in love. The whole village, the whole neighborhood, the whole country talks of it. They are in love with a vagrant, who will be cited to appear before the magistracy, to-morrow, and be sent over the boundaries next day.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir, can you prove your accusation?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Pshaw! The world seldom requires proofs. The worse any thing appears to be, the readier it is believed.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Alas! True.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: I, therefore, advise you as a friend, Mr. Welling, and I advise you, Mrs. Welling, to keep a watchful eye upon these two love-sick damsels, and as to the gentle rhymster—to-morrow before the magistracy!—Dixi.
sp.stage: Paulina and Rosa burst into a fit of laughter.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am not pleased to seeing you laugh.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Dear father, he is only a fool.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How often have I told you that fools do more mischief in the world than villains! A villain is generally possessed of sense, and does not deal in defamation, unless he can thereby attain some end, but a fool is continually prating. I, therefore, merely go out of a rascal's road, but I conceal myself from a blockhead. As to what Ernorf said, it cannot be his own invention.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: It is indeed. The whole secret is, that Lewis writes better poetry than he does.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Perhaps I have too much relied upon the idea that fraternal intercourse is seldom dangerous to the heart. Perhaps the young man has really made some impression upon you. Surveys them attentively. How!—Silent!—Have your parents lost your confidence?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh no!—I really like Lewis very much—but I don't love him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And you, Paulina?—You cast down your eyes.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Stammering. I own, father—that I think Lewis—the most amiable man I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You mean, in other words—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I can't express it by words; but I feel that if I were allowed to love him— With a sigh. I should love him most ardently.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How long have you known this sensation?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I almost feel as if I had been born with it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Did he himself endeavor to gain your affections?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Never. You know how reserved and bashful he is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: So much the more dangerous is he to a woman's heart.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Sighing. True, dear mother.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: The same. Yes, true indeed.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Do you believe your affection is returned?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Perhaps because you wish it?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I see but two modes of settling this. Lewis must either marry you, or leave the house.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Fearfully. Which shall you embrace?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Let us hear your mother's opinion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Well—Lewis is a good young man—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: But poor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: So were you, my dear William.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: We don't know who he is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Nor did we know who you were.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes, yes. Your father knew it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I don't know it to this very hour.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Oh! If I were in twenty-five years to know Lewis as well as you know my father—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Paulina, I can explain no further, but before Lewis can become my son-in-law, I must learn his fortunes, and must be convinced his conduct has always been as praiseworthy as since he lived with us. Go, Rosa, and call him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Would you just to-day—?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Instantly, or I should not enjoy the pleasures of to-day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Go, then, Paulina, it is not proper that you should be present on this occasion.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Oh! If it were proper, I am sure I could not stay.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Lewis is become dear to me by his honesty and diligence—perhaps still more so, by a certain similarity in our fates. If, therefore, I find every thing accordant to my wishes, and you have no objection—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: It would certainly be the best means of silencing the world.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I understand you want me.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Did Rosa tell you for what purpose?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: The under-secretary dislikes you.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Because my verses are liked.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He insists upon knowing who you are.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: That he will not learn.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: If the secretary unites with him—

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: And you cannot protect me, I will go.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Will that be so easy to you?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: No. Very difficult.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You may avoid it.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Tell us your story.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You have lived with us two years. I have observed you narrowly, and am sure you are incapable of a crime.—If you have been guilty of any juvenile indiscretion, avow it. You know my sentiments.

sp.speaker: Lew
sp.p: My conscience does not accuse me of a crime, or even levity. I am only unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: We will assist you in sustaining your misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I must sustain them alone; for if I confess them, I shall be acting against a sacred duty.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Enough! Let us drop the subject.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Our intentions were good.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Oh, you have not confined yourselves to intentions. Your house was my asylum, and the small measure of enjoyment, of which my heart was susceptible, you have bestowed on me.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: We would willingly double it by reconciling you to your fate.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Let me then dwell in private as hitherto. Do not, do not rob me of the bliss I feel in calling you my parents.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I would not do it for my own sake, were I not compelled to it. When you entered my house, my daughters were still almost children, and we thought not that your presence would ever injure their reputation.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: You alarm me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Do you now perceive why it was necessary we should speak to you.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Oh God! yes.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: If you be such a man as I have fancied you, I may at once declare, that not only the reputation, but the peace of one of my daughters depends on your departure.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: After a pause. I will go.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I acted imprudently in having desired Paulina to consider you as her brother, and in having been silent, while her attachment increased.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Oh! I would fall at your feet, and say—"Consider not my poverty, but look at my heart, and let me marry your Paulina,"—but—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You do not love her?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I love her from my soul.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And yet—?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: After a pause. I am already married.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Married!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And have forsaken your wife?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Condemn me not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Shaking her head. Such conduct, Lewis—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Do not reproach him, Ann. If he be guilty, he bears a judge within himself, before whom he cannot be a hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Oh! you will send me away far poorer than I was when I came, if my confession has robbed me of your regard.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I do not decide upon it. Two years of upright conduct are to be placed in competition with this apparently bad action and—I do not decide. But my duty as a father, commands me seriously to repeat that your presence disturbs the tranquility of my family.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Shall I depart to-day—immediately?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: After a moment's consideration. It will hurt me not to see you sitting to-night among my children—but—act as you think I have deserved.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Oh! Allow me to remain one hour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Yes, Lewis, he did not mean it in that light. Stay 'till morning.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I will creep into some corner, and not disturb your happiness—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Oh that this should just happen to-day!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Let me but wander once more through the house and garden. When the guests come, I will steal away.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Not without taking leave?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I cannot take leave of you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Lewis, do you think we wish to turn you out of doors like a dishonest servant? Despair shall not force you to enlist again. I know my husband. He parts with you because he feels he must; but he will not abandon you—I will not abandon you. What he will do for you I don't know, but— Secretly draws from her pocket a small leather purse.—for my part, my love and blessing shall be a substitute for what is wanting—in the amount. Puts the purse into his hand, wipes her eyes, and exit hastily.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: After a pause, during which he mournfully surveys the purse. Wretched outcast that I am! Have I at length found a mother, only to be doomed doubly to feel the loss of her? Have I gained a lovely girl's affections, only to make my chains the heavier? He stands in an attitude of deep reflection and despondency.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Softly steals behind him, and puts her hands upon his eyes. Guess who it is. Draws her hands back with sudden alarm, and looks at them. What does this mean? Your eyes are full of tears.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: You should not have seen them.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Why are you in tears?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: They are the lot of humanity.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: What is the matter? What has happened? What have you to do with my mother's purse?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: After a pause. It contains money to defray the expenses of my journey.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Terrified. Are you going to leave us?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I must.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Any where. The further, the better.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Have you, then, staid too long with us?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Much too long.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: With a sigh. I almost think so, myself.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Gives her his hand. You have always been kind and affectionate towards me.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: With innocence and fervor. I am so still. Somewhat confused. My father—wanted to speak to you.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: He has done it.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: And does he approve of your intention?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I go by his desire.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Your answers are enigmas.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p:
My whole being is an enigma, which death alone can solve.—Farewell, Paulina—do not forget me. I have loved all this family—but you particularly.—Wherever I go,
your image will accompany me. When you sit under the great lime-tree—think sometimes of me.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Lewis!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Remember me to the old woman, who used to receive your charities through me.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Bursts into tears. Lewis, what does this mean? If you love me—

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: My affection for you is a crime—my heart is sinning against a hateful duty.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Oh! Speak more plainly, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Yes, good Paulina, you shall not learn from another what separates us. It is hard to tell you—but tell you I must, that—I am married.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Almost shrieking. Married!—That is not true.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Would to God it were not!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Married!—Oh Lewis! Why did you conceal it?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Do not hate me.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Go, go to your wife, and tell her you have robbed Paulina of her peace for ever. Coveys her face with both hands, and rushes out.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Paulina! Is that your farewell? Strikes his forehead, and rests his head against the wall.

div.head: SCENE—A WOOD.
div.p: Count Lohrstein is discovered in the back ground, sleeping under a tree—at his head lies a casket. Francis and Jacob are in conversation towards the front of the stage.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: He is asleep. What think you, Jacob? Do you chuse to follow him through woods and bogs any longer? It's a strange kind of inclination.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Scratching his head. It's not exactly inclination.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Why, a dog leads a better life.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: But our master himself fares no better.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: The cook was the wisest of us, for he ran away, when he had only travelled one stage.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: The count smiled at that; but last night when his valet disappeared, on whom he placed such firm reliance—

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Yes, yes—no doubt he took some valuable effects with him. My advice is, Jacob, that we do the same.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What! Leave the old gentleman quite alone!

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Why, he must dismiss us in a day or two, for how can he support us?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: That's true, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: And how long shall we be able to endure such a life at this? We have passed six nights in the open air. If we espy a chimney, we leave it a quarter of a mile on one side. We buy our coarse bread at solitary shepherd's huts, and have nothing to drink but water from the springs we meet with.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: But we have known better days in his service.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Was it our fault that there was an end to those days? Who knows what crime he has committed? The prince would scarcely send huzzars in pursuit of him for nothing.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Damn those fellows! They nearly caught us once or twice.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: And if they should catch us, we may perhaps be doomed to keep our master company in prison.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: But we must be near the borders now.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Well—can't the huzzars ride over the borders?—Besides, we are now in a worse situation than ever. Our horses are so tired that we shall be obliged to leave them, and if we be seen creeping through the thickets, we may be mistaken for robbers, and shot.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hang it, Francis, you frighten me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Therefore, I say, let us be off before he awakes. Believe me, we shall be doing him a kindness.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: If I thought so—

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: He won't dismiss us, and he can't pay us. But if, when he awakes, he finds we have decamped, he'll be heartily glad to have got rid of us.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Casting a glance towards the Count. See! He begins to move.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Let us lose no more time. Does he owe you any wages?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Yes, for a couple of months.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: And me for a quarter of a year. We can't afford to make him a present of that. In the casket, there, he has several trinkets, rings, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Surely you would not take them?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Blockhead! Why not?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What! Rob him?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Doesn't he owe us money?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: But not so much.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Pshaw! Who knows what the baubles are worth? We can sell them at the first place we come to, and if they produce more than is due to us, we can send it to him by the post.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why, yes, if that can be done—

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Follow that foot-path. I'll be with you in a minute.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Good old master! I pity him, nevertheless.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Walks gently to the count, takes the casket, and then returns on tip-toe. When arrived at some yards distance, he bows sarcastically. Good bye to your excellency! Your lordship will now not be over-burdened.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p:
Tormented by frightful dreams. Oh! not into this subterraneous dungeon.—Give me air!—Give me air!— Awakes. Where am I?— Raises himself. Heaven be praised, not yet in the hands of my persecutors—not yet in the power of the most abandoned of women.—Alas! My sleep has not refreshed me.—The rain has drenched my clothes:—I must hasten towards the borders, that I may at least find a house, where I may die. Raises himself with difficulty. Perhaps my people have, meanwhile, discovered a safe path. Calls. Francis! Jacob! The honest fellows are endeavouring to find the shortest road through the thickets.—Francis! Jacob!—Yet I ordered them not to go far.—Where can they be? My strength is exhausted, and I am no longer able to call. Exerting himself. Francis! Jacob!—What can this mean?—No answer!—Can they—impossible!— Draws out a littl whistle, gives a signal towards different quarters, and listens for a reply. Not yet?—Can they too have forsaken me?—Must I then despair of finding honesty among mankind?— His casket suddenly occurs to him—he looks at the place where it lay, and strikes his forehead. Yes. 'Tis true.—Forsaken and robbed!—They have deprived me of my last resource.— Rivets his eyes on the earth—a pause.—Here do I stand—I, who but ten days ago possessed half a million—and have not now a morsel of bread to share with my dog— Looks hastily around. Sultan! Sultan!—Alas! My dog too has forsaken me. A pause of dreadful anguish. — God protect me from insanity! I'll tear a bough from yonder tree, and wander through the wood—then, if I hunger, I must gnaw the bark from my staff. — Yes, they have plundered me, and stolen from my heart all confidence in God or man.— Feels his pockets. Nothing, nothing have
they left me.— Stops suddenly. Yes, yes—they have. One friend I still possess.— Draws out a pistol. Welcome thou friend in need, thou last resource of a despairing man! A pause. Answer me, philosophy, thou sweet companion of my better days, thou phantom of my brain—I am now in earnest—answer me. May that man, who has been hurled from the pinnacle of greatness into the gulph of misery, who has been sold by a faithless wife, and whom each step conducts to an eternal prison.—May that man, who has no child, no friend, no hope— Puts the pistol to his forehead.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: As he is passing, hears part of the above soliloquy, rushes towards the Count, and wrenches the pistol from his hand. Hold!—Zounds! That must not be.—An old man, too! How short a time will it be ere death of his own accord will summon you?

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Oh that he would!

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: This trigger is soon pulled, but how do you expect to be received above?—Understood?

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Oh, my friend! Your intentions are, doubtless good, but a man in despair has no ear for your cool precepts.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Why, you are right there, to be sure. But can I help you, eh?

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: I am a wretched fugitive, pursued by enemies, and forsaken by every friend.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: H-m!—I could ask why, but there is no time for that just now. If, therefore, I can be of any assistance to you, I will with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Are we far from the borders?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: A hundred yards, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Oh tell me instantly—to the right or left?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Where you see a little bridge over the stream yonder. But which way are you going?

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Any way. I only wish to find a hovel or barn where I can rest 'till morning, for I have slept six nights beneath the canopy of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Do you suppose, then, we have no beds, eh?

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: I have been robbed and can only pay with gratitude.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: I'll take you to a house where that coin is always current. At night you shall come home with me, but at present we'll go to a cottage hard by, for you seem in want of refreshment.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Generous man, who are you?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Henry Dalner, chief forester of this district—but that's of no consequence—Understood?—I'll take you to an old farmer, who is celebrating his twenty-sixth wedding-day.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Uneasy. I wish we were beyond the borders.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Farmer Welling lives just on the other side of them. Oh? there comes his son. He'll soon be my son too.—Understood?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Well, father, where's Louisa.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: She is staying to nurse her old aunt, and can't come 'till evening.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: But couldn't the maid have nursed the old aunt?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: That old aunt acted as a mother to Louisa, and never entrusted her education to the maid.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I came to meet you in such spirits—

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: You shall not have come in vain, for though you don't find Louisa, you find an opportunity of doing good. Here is a poor man, whom I have promised to take with me, and I hope you will receive my guest kindly.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Of course. If he be unfortunate, he needs no recommendation.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Look in good humor, then.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: How can I, when Louisa is not at home? To the Count. Don't mind my countenance, sir. At night, when Louisa is with me, you'll see me in spirits.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Come, then—

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Exhausted. Good man lend me your stick.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Pshaw! As long as I have an arm, why should I lend my stick. Understood?

div.head: SCENE—WELLING'S HOUSE.
div.p: Mrs. Welling is discovered at her needle-work. Welling brings Lewis in.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I have brought a man, whom I surprised, as he was endeavoring to escape through the back door, without having taken leave.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Indeed! would he not even accept this linen which I have been selecting for him?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: You have already given me so much—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Pst!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: And my father has been so generous.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Silence! I did not bring you hither to hear myself praised.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Oh! how painful do I find it to bid you farewell!—I had rather forsake the world than this house.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: We are travellers, whose journey has hitherto been the same way; but we have now reached the cross road, and must part.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Adieu, then, father—adieu, good mother. Whereever my road may conduct me, it will never lead to ingratitude.—Words fail me at this bitter hour—God sees my heart—and you my tears.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Much affected. A father's benediction be upon thee, youth! May'st thou, like me, at length enjoy the blessings of affection, industry and health, and thank Providence for having, by early sufferings, enhanced the value of your later bliss.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Let us often hear where you are, and how you do.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And, Lewis, if you should ever be in want of any thing—you have given me your promise?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: You have taught me to work.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: But you may fall sick.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: With a look towards Heaven, expressive of his wishes. And die.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: You break my heart.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Go, my son. It is time that we should part.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Follows and embraces him. Alas! It was thus I felt when my eldest boy died—His name was Lewis, too—I have lost him—who knows whether I shall ever see you again?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Let him go, good Ann. He has enough to bear.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Scarcely able to speak. Father, grant me my last request.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Willingly, my son.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Let me see Paulina once again.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Would you add to the horrors of the separation?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Oh, let me see her once again.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To Mrs. W. Where is she?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: In her own room.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Let her come.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Goes to the door and opens it. Paulina! Lewis is here, and wishes to bid you farewell.

div.stage: Her eyes are red with weeping — She gives Lewis her hand. — They stand opposite each other silent and trembling. — A long pause.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: With great emotion. Embrace each other, children.

div.stage: Lewis and Paulina embrace. Paulina walks sobbing to her chamber, and Lewis rushes out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Following him. Lewis—the linen!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Short-sighted mortals! Thus you often do harm, while striving to do good. Had I left this poor youth to his fate, perhaps, ere now, some cannot-ball might have swept him from the world. He would then have been happy.—Well, be this as it may, I will not cease to do what conviction tells me is right.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Father, Lewis is gone.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I know it.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I heard him sob, as he disappeared behind the hedge.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: God be with him!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My mother is in tears.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Go, and console her.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I shall only weep with her.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Go, then, to your sister.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Father, you are, in general, so good—tell me—why may not Paulina marry him?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Because he is already married.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Already married!—Then, she must submit to her fate.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: She will, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: And is that the only reason why Lewis is obliged to leave us?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Not because he is poor?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Timidly advancing towards her object. You would have let him marry Paulina, in spite of his poverty?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I would!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: And if I were—to like a man—who was not married—but poor—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: If he were honest and industrious—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Eagerly. That he is.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Much confused. I mean—but you are not angry, dear father?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: At what?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I would have told you it sooner—but I only learnt it myself an hour or two ago.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: That I—that I love Mr. Rehberg.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Indeed! And how did you learn it?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: He asked me about it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And you, with your usual openness—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I referred him to you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He has not mentioned the subject to me.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh, he durst not. You frightened him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: You railed against the poverty of professional men.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Hence, then, the sensibility which I remarked.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: But I am certain he misunderstood you. Honesty and industry are all the qualifications my father requires.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: But as I told him, the industry of a professional man will not always support a family. You are but sixteen years of age, and can wait.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: For Rehberg!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why not? If in a few years he should obtain a moderate living, and his sentiments, as well as your's, remain the same—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh! There is no doubt of that.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why, then, we can talk further on the subject.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: But now? What shall I say to him?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: But he is walking so sorrowfully in the garden.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Go, then, and send him hither.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Stroking his cheek. Dear father!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Talk kindly to him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I almost think I see a tear in your eye.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I love him so sincerely.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Alone. Rehberg is a sensible man, and that is all I know of him.—But who can decide whether poverty or affection be the another of his wishes?—Wretched indeed would be my Rosa, if she borrowed charms from her father's coffers.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: With reserve. Rosa has just told me—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Half joking, half in earnest. My dear sir, she has told you many things too soon, and I must own I had rather have heard from you, what she has just confessed to me.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Appearances are against me.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yet good news is welcome from any one.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: How happy should I be, if I could think you serious!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Can I make a joke of my daughter's happiness? When I tell you that I have observed qualities in you which claim my respect, I speak the truth.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: The respect of a worthy man satisfies my ambition, but not my heart.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: After a pause. Our relative situations give me a right to be candid with you.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I shall evade no question you may please to ask.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You have enemies.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: That is a compliment to me.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: He who injures no man, and yet has enemies, cannot be a common kind of man.
