sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The secretary's house is not in the best repute. You are often there.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Because I give lessons in music there, as well as here.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: It is said you admire one of his daughters.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I have heard as much.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And do not cease your visits?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: No. Because there no regard is paid to so absurd a report, and I myself cannot afford to renounce the profits of my attendance.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why not?—Forgive me if I seem too forward.—You are a single man.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I have a poor mother.—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: But it is said you play—and play for large sums.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: To this assertion I shall answer with a mere No.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You do not play?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I have once or twice taken the cards of another, when called away—I myself never play.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You had, as I am told, a good library?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I had.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You sold it?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: With a sigh. I did.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I have heard that the money you obtained for it was lost at the secretary's card-table.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: That is an infamous falsehood.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I guess—your poor mother—

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Confused. No. After a pause. 'Tis well. I will not conceal from you even this circumstance, but I beg you to believe that nothing but my present situation should induce me to disclose it. I am of low origin, and my father was seized with the pious whim of making me a clergyman, without being able to bestow any thing on my education. My humble talents, however, procured me a patron, who was in easy circumstances, and who defrayed the expenses of my studies. To him I was obliged for every thing; and the library you have mentioned, was his present. About a year ago, this worthy man was plundered by the French, and obliged in his age to become a beggar. It was then I sold my books.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And sent him the money?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I could do no more for him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I know enough, and as you are not satisfied with my respect Offers his hand. accept my admiration—regard—affection—

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: With warmth. Will you be my father?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Good Rehberg! You consider not what weighty duties already rest on you. A poor mother—a poor benefactor—and a wife too—children — or do you calculate on my daughter's fortune?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Perhaps you have prospects at our vicar's death?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: None.—I had prospects elsewhere, but within an hour my hopes from that quarter have been destroyed, and had I sooner received the intelligence I would have been silent.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Explain yourself.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I had succeeded in interesting some men of consequence for me at the neighboring court.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Starts. At the neighboring court!

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: A pamphlet, in which at least my patriotic zeal was evident, excited the attention of the minister.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Confused and agitated. The minister. Oh, I know him.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: He is a man of great influence—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: He has large estates—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: True—he has—confiscated estates.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Among others, the living of Birkendorf is in his gift.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Aside. Birkendorf! Oh God!

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: This living was described to me as a very profitable one, and the place as comfortable and retired.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Suppressing his agitation. Oh! 'Tis a sweet place—I was once there. — Well? You received a promise—?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I was almost certain of success.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And were, nevertheless, disappointed? By what means?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Of that I am ignorant. A letter, which I received about an hour ago, briefly states that unexpected circumstances have taken place, which deprive me of all hope at present.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am sorry, good Rehberg, I am sorry that I cannot make you vicar of Birkendorf, but it really is not in my power.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Somewhat surprised. That I know.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yet—if you have resolution enough to wait—you shall have Rosa.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Enraptured. Thanks, dearest sir! I care not how rough the path, if she be the object to which it leads.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I should have liked to have visited you at Birkendorf very much—oh, very much.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: My dear William, our neighbor Dalner is bringing another guest with him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Frederick says, he found him in the wood.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I don't like strangers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: A poor man in distress—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Then he is welcome. I should ill deserve my present happiness, were I on such a day as this to send a fellow, creature in distress from my door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Poor Lewis!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: We have lost a son in him—but here stands a man who will supply his place.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: With formal civility. Indeed!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come, come, Ann. I have proved him, and will be surety for him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The reports you heard are false.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I am glad they are.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Pshaw, wife! You don't speak from your heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: With warmth. Indeed I am glad.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He is a good son, and a grateful man.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: With diffidence. Dear Mr. Welling!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You know, Ann, that I only give this title to those who remain so longer than the kindness itself endures, and whose gratitude is not like a crayon picture, which every year loses a portion of its colours. Such men are rare, and he is one of them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I am ashamed of having done him an injustice.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Embrace him, then, as your future son-in-law.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: With all my heart!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: That is, as soon as he obtains a living, which will banish all cares for subsistence. Instil this idea in Rosa's mind, and tell her to be patient.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: But, my dear husband, why delay their happiness? With our fortune—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You know my sentiments. A good wife is so great a treasure, that I am not at all surprised when I read of nations who receive money from the bridegroom, when they bestow a daughter upon him. A girl ought to have no dowry but beauty and virtue. Thus thought your father—thus think I.—

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Who would not think such a dowry sufficient?

div.stage: Enter Mr. DALNER, Count LOHRSTEIN, and FREDERICK.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Father, Louisa is not come.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: With your permission, neighbor, I'll introduce a stranger.
sp.stage: Welling gazes full at the Count.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Encouraged by this worthy man, I have ventured to intrude upon you.
sp.stage: Welling, without making any reply, surveys him with close attention.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: You are sincerely welcome.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: If misfortunes give me any claim on your compassion—

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Whispering to Welling, who stands like a statue. Speak a kind word, or two. He is a poor fellow, whom fate seems to have dealt hardly by. I found him in the wood just when he was going— Imitates the action of holding the pistol to his head. Understood?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Recovering. I—sir—I rejoice—consider my house as your own—and, if you are in search of an asylum—you have found it.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: I thank you. That is the first word of consolation I have heard after six days of horror. Am I over the borders, here?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Always agitated. You are.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: In safety, then?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Perfectly.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: And if my pursuers were even to force their way hither—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Here dwells no traitor.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Your hand, honest old man!— Welling gives it. The trembling of it might make me suspicious—

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Never fear, sir. This man's promise, with a shake of the hand, is as safe as a bond with a dozeh seals to it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: In a broken voice. My wife—and my children—will take care—that you want nothing.—I myself—forgive me—I must leave you for a few moments.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Alarmed. What is the matter, dear William?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Neighbor, you grow pale.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am not well. Frederick and Mrs. W. run to him.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Father!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Let me go—it will soon be over—I'll step into my chamber—stay—stay—I wish to be alone. Reels a few steps—then supports himself on a chair, which stands near him. I cannot—Frederick—assist me.— Frederick runs and conducts him to the chamber.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Heavens! What is this?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: A serious accident. To Rehberg. Something like an apoplectic fit.

div.stage: Welling having reached the door, is unable any longer to keep his feet, and sinks into the arms of his son.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Shrieks. He is dying! He is dying!
sp.stage: Dalner and Rehberg hasten to his assistance.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Heaven forbid!

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Put him to bed directly.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Alone. Of all my followers none has remained with me but misery. Am I then doomed to bring sorrow into this peaceful hut too?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Rushes from her chamber. Paulina! Rosa! Your father—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Without. What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Meeting her. My father is ill. We must send for a surgeon directly.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Without paying any attention to the stranger. Heavens! So suddenly!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Without. My father! My father!
sp.stage: Rushes shrieking across the stage into the chamber.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Returning—as he crosses the stage. Oh God! Help us! Help us!

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Alone. Oh that I could die thus! Oh that I had children, who thus loved me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p:
With Paulina. There's the key—in the little
cupboard—on the right—a brown vial—or on the left—or right—oh, I don't know. Returns. Paulina runs out.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Alone, and deeply moved. I thank thee, God!—I still can feel for other's woes.

div.stage: Paulina crosses the stage with the vial in her hand, and sobbing violently.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Alone What was my rank—my splendid station? What has my life been, compared with this man's death?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Gently pushing Mrs. W. and her daughters out of the chamber. Pshaw! Your groans and cries only make the evil the greater. Pray stay here. Nothing shall be neglected.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Transported beyond herself. Heavens! After living twenty-five years with him, must I leave him at his dying hour?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Mother, he will not die.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh no, no! He will not die.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Let me go to fulfil my duty. When you were born, Paulina, and I was dangerously ill, your father never left my side.—Shall I then leave him in the hands of strangers?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Opens the door. Be quiet. He recovers.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Did you hear that, mother? He recovers.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Falling on Mrs. Welling's neck. Mother! Mother! Rejoice! Heaven will restore him to us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Is it, then true? Oh yes! It must be true. God will not separate two such loving hearts.—Come, children, kneel, and pray with me for your father's recovery. Sinks on her knees. Paulina and Rosa kneel on each side of her. All raise their hands towards Heaven, and pray.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: From the chamber. Joy! Mother! My father is come to himself again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Stretches her arms towards him—He raises her. Frederick, I thought I had blessed you as far as I was able—I was mistaken—Heaven bless you a thousand times for this intelligence!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Hanging on him. Are you sure of it, brother?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: The same. Is all the danger over?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I believe it is. He can stand again. He is only rather weak, and has just drank a glass of wine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: May I, then, go to him? In a tone of intreaty. Yes, yes. Let me go to him.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Good mother, this has affected you very much. Come! I'll support you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I have him again.—Oh God! Forgive me—as yet I cannot thank thee. Goes slowly towards the chamber supported by Frederick. The door opens.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: See! There he is!

div.stage: Welling appears at the door, leaning on Dalner and Rehberg.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Flies into his arms. My husband!

div.stage: The three children kneel round him, the Count stands in a corner, and casts a look of bitter sorrow on the group.

div.head: ACT THE FOURTH.
div.p: Welling is discovered, sitting in the middle of the stage, surrounded by his wife and children. On each side of him stand Dalner and Rehberg—the Count is more towards the front of the stage.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Good Ann, be at ease. It is over.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Won't you put on your bed-grown?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I'll go for it.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I'll fetch your slippers.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Will you, then, make me ill by compulsion? I tell you I am well. Give me a glass of wine. That is all I want.
sp.stage: Mrs. W. and her daughters runs to the door.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Hold! Why you need not all go for it.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I was the first.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: No—I was.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No—I was.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: And I am your mother. Where are the keys?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You know, Ann, I don't like you any longer to fatigue yourself by going into the cellar.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: There—you hear mother—I am to go.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: No, it is my week.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: You have nothing to do with the cellar. Your week only relates to the kitchen.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: But I love my father as much as you do.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Children at this rate, I shall not have any thing. I love you both. Go, both of you.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Neighbor, I am thinking that▪ what is passing round you must revive you more than wine. Understood?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: True. If there be any medicine, which can promote long life, it must be affection.

div.stage: One brings a bottle—the other a silver goblet.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Number 4.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: With a black seal.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: There is Hochheim upon it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Drinks and says to Rosa. Fill it. She obeys—he turns to the Count. Sir, I am sorry that, added to your own misfortunes, you have been obliged to witness the distress of others.— Raises the goblet.—According to the ancient custom of our country I sincerely bid you welcome.

div.stage: Paulina takes the goblet and delivers it to the Count with a curtsey.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p:
Empties it. To the health of my worthy bost!—Now, sir, if you really remain true to the customs of our
forefathers, I am secure in your house, for we have drank from the same goblet.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Here lurks no traitor.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Spies gain nothing here.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: But a drubbing.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: And contempt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: If you be weary, sir, I'll conduct you to a retired chamber.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: You shall sleep on linen which we wove ourselves.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: And feathers of our own geese.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Heaven be praised that I again find myself among men! All I see and hear inspires confidence. I should like, good old man, to have a little conversation with you in private.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: With all my heart! My friends, and children, you will find employment enough, if you will go into the court, and assist in the preparations for our little country feast.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: I sent you a few poles for the occasion, from the forest.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: And I made the garlands for them.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Mr. Rehberg will teach us a chorus, in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I can't sing, but I can join with my violin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: You'll not be long before you follow us?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: As soon as possible.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Generous man, it is my duty to make a discovery of my rank and situation to you, that you may know you are not harboring a criminal.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Of a crime I hold Count Lohrstein to be incapable.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Alarmed. How! You know me.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Stedfastly. Yes, Count, business has sometimes carried me to your Prince's residence, where I have seen you.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Then you are probably not ignorant what rank and honors I possessed but a few days since?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You were your Prince's all-powerful minister.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: In reality an office, but all adapted to my inclination. Alas! There was a time, when domestic felicity in the arms of my first consort left me no other wish.—She died.—I forsook my solitary country dwelling, rushed into the whirlpool of the city to dissipate my grief and to seek another affectionate heart; instead of which I found a deceitful and ambitious woman, who from an admirer of a country life transformed me into a courtier, and used me as the tool of her designs.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I know the Countess, too.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: By situations for ever new and intricate she kept me remote from nature and affection. By inexhaustible intrigues and plots she, for a train of years, bound to our house the favor of the court, 'till the old Prince, feeling the approach of death—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: In involuntary agitation. He died?

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Some months previous to his dissolution, my wife, in combination with an abandoned daughter-in-law, engendered new plans. She knew the hereditary Prince disliked me, and that his father's death would be the signal for my dismissal; but she also knew the connection which subsisted between the young Prince and my daughter-in-law. With her, therefore, she began to cabal, finding she could no longer maintain her station by her own devices. Two furies suppressed the hatred which had endured for years, and the snakes from their hair were intertwined. Over powered with agony. Oh!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: It is to your praise, my lord, that you were not invited to share in this coalition.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p:
I was. I had been persuaded to so many things—had so often despotically forced my heart to silence, that, on this occasion too, they thought their game an easy one. Yet although I had breathed none but court-air for seven-and-twenty years, I found it impossible to cringe to a woman, who had plunged my son into misery, and branded my
name with infamy. I was not even able to suppress some severe remarks occasioned by the abandoned life of my daughter-in-law. She thirsted for revenge, and my wife prudently took the strongest side. The Prince died—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: With an involuntary sigh. He was a good man, and not formed for the intrigues of a court.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Astonished. Your opinion is just. How happens it that you—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Interrupting him. It was not exactly my opinion. Proceed, my lord.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: I was prepared to receive my dismissal, but not to give account of every weakness, which might be laid to my charge during the twenty-seven years of my administration, of every injustice perhaps, to which at the pressing instigation of my wife and her adherents, I had now and then been led. I was not prepared against proofs, which my wife had stolen from my cabinet, and lodged in the hands of my enemies.—Her reward was the permission to remain at court, and wander like the ghost of her former greatness, while I was doomed to perpetual imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Which you escaped by flight?

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Forsaken by all, who had been obliged to me for their situations, I was apprized of the impending danger by an old man, for whom I had done nothing—whom I had always considered as a cypher. Heaven's blessings be shed on honest Zahn!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Starts. Zahn!

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: At the peril of losing his scanty subsistence, he forced his way at midnight to my chamber. "My Lord," said he, "I am under no obligation to you, and I do not like you; but you are about to be ill-treated. Fly, or at break of day you will be imprisoned in the castle."

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Aside. Such conduct is what I should expect of honest Zahn.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p:
I fled—and was pursued with such alacrity and fury as none but female vengeance could devise. Twice have
I been surrounded by hussars. My escape was almost a miracle, and who knows whether even here—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Be at ease, my Lord. No force shall intrude upon you here. You are on the borders of a just Prince, and in the house of a man, who honors hospitality.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: You engage I am secure?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: And will you allow me to remain with you, 'till a trusty friend, informed of my situation, can assist me in proceeding further?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: As long as you please.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: For I must confess to you that my sudden flight allowed me to rescue but little, and even this little has been stolen by people, on whose fidelity I relied.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Command my purse.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Good man, you carry your generosity too far.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Not so, my lord. I merely pay an old debt.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: To me!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I too was once a wretched fugitive, and therefore consider every unfortunate man as a creditor sent by God.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Dear William, I beg pardon for disturbing you, but the people below are talking about soldiers.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Alarmed. What kind of soldiers?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: They are listening and looking among the bushes in the wood—they certainly are on no good errand.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Who can know that; for we live peaceably? They are, perhaps, looking for strawberries.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Father, there are hussars belonging to the neighboring Prince in the village.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Oh God!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Well, what is that to us?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: They go from house to house, and break open every room that is locked, like robbers.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Then they must be taken into custody, like robbers.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: They are in search of somebody.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: They have no right to search here.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Father, there are hussars at the gate.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Let the gate be locked.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: They have been asking our men whether there was not a stranger in the house.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And what answer was returned?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: As you had not forbidden it, the men told the truth.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The truth is never forbidden in my house.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: I am lost.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Be at ease. I am surety for your safety.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: The whole court is full of hussars.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My dear Ann, these people have had a great deal of trouble to no purpose. Give them a little beer.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: They insist with violence on your delivering up a prisoner.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: They will be more civil, when they learn my determination.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: They threaten.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How many of them are there?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: About twenty.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Then their threats are ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Oh, rather deliver me into their hands. Shall I plunge you too, worthy man, and your whole family into ruin?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, I have pledged to you my word, that you are in safety. I will abide by it.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: The devil has let loose a set of rascals, who act as if they were in an enemy's country.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Paulina, send some one by the back way into the village, and ask a dozen young fellows to come hither.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: How! Would you oppose them?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Be patient. We shall not be obliged to have recourse to extremities.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Hark ye, Rosa. Send a man to my house with orders that all the foresters come hither directly with their guns, and hangers. Do you hear?

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Oh, sir! Return me the friend, of whom you robbed me in the wood.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Be quiet. Not a hair of your head shall be touched, by God. Understood?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Without. Back!

sp.speaker: Brave.
sp.p: The same. Out of my way, boy!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: This is not a pot-house.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Let him come, my son.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Sees the Count. Ha! Ha! Have I found you at last? Follow me, my Lord, without opposition.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Sir, the person, in whose hands you are an instrument—

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I am not an instrument, but a servant of my Prince. Come with me instantly. The carriage waits.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Suppressing his anger. But you must know, sir, that in this country it is not usual for people to break into a house, like a hawk into a lark's nest—understood?—You must know, sir, that we understand a little law, if you do not.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Attacking him on the other side. And you must know that the carriage may perhaps wait some time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Pulling him away. Frederick!

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Who are you, and what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: We are people who belong to this place—understood?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Yes, and the word of command is: To the right about face, and ride home again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Pulling him away. Frederick! Frederick!

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: What! Dare you attempt by abusive language—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Hold, hold! Your pardon, sir. My friend and son are rather incensed at the illegal way in which you have entered this house.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Illegal! How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How! I am the master of this house, and know my privileges.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I want nothing of you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: But you want to take away one, who is enjoying the rights of hospitality here. You want to do it by compulsion.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I hope you will be rational, and not oblige me to do so.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I beg you will produce your orders.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: My orders! I don't know that I am answerable to you for my conduct—but that is of no consequence. Here are my orders.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Opens the paper. You are surely joking, lieutenant. These orders are not from my Prince.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: But they are from mine.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To whom I owe no obedience.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: But I do, and by my soul I have neglected it too long.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I do not perceive one syllable in these orders, which justifies you in disturbing the dominions of a neighboring Prince.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Enough! I know how far I dare proceed.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Has your Prince commanded this?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I am not bound to answer that question.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And will mine submit to it?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: With that I have nothing to do. In a word, the Count will please to come with me.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: In a word, lieutenant, he shall not.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Starts. Shall not!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Emphatically. No.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Sir, I advise you to retract this declaration, or it will be the cause of blood-shed.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Father, there are not twelve, but forty of the villagers assembled in the court, and armed with forks.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Do you hear, lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: We are not afraid of such rabble.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Mr. Dalner, the foresters are running down the hill.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: These, sir, are my lads, armed with guns and hangers.—Marksmen, sir, who can hit a button. Understood?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: You surely do not mean to oppose my orders. Beware what you do. The Count is a criminal.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: That am I not.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Lieutenant, you and I are no longer young. Let us have a little conversation together, in private. Strange will it be, if men like us, cannot part with each other on friendly terms.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My dear Ann, take your daughters into another room.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: In a tone of apprehension. But, dearest husband—

sp.speaker: Pau. and Ros.
sp.p: Dear father!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Be at ease. There is no danger. Mr. Rehberg, be kind enough to accompany them. Your assurances of my safety may make them less afraid.
sp.stage: Exeunt Mrs. W. Pau. Ros. and Reh.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To Dalner. Go you, my friend, with Frederick into the court, and see that our peasants do not begin a quarrel with the hussars.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: I will. Not one of them shall move.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: But if the hussars behave improperly, I'll not answer for them.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Calls after him in a serious tone. I command you to keep them quiet. You, my Lord, will be kind enough to step into the next room.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Hold! I shall not allow my prisoner to be out of sight.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: After a pause. Well, then, he may remain here.—I did not indeed wish—but circumstances make it necessary. He must, however, promise not to interrupt our conversation.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: You know that here I must obey, and you, generous man, I willingly obey.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Wave all further preface, for my time is short.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Enough!—Lieutenant, you seem determined rigidly to follow your instructions.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I have been thirty years in service, and must know what I have to do.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: But I well know, that in the execution of severe orders, you have not always been so exact.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Mr. Farmer, or whatever else you may be, this is very presumptuous language to an old officer.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Had you never before any orders of a similar nature?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: None that I recollect.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: It is, I own, a long time ago, and the circumstances may have escaped your memory. About twenty-seven years since, when Baron Wellingrode fled— Brave starts. were not you sent in pursuit of him?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Somewhat confused. How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I know still more. You overtook him, made him a prisoner in your own Prince's territories, and yet—allowed him to escape.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: H-m—yes—I remember—he escaped.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: With your consent.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Who says that?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You ventured it at the risk of being cashiered.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Who can prove that?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You even shared your purse with him.—You were then a youth, whose heart could feel for the misfortunes of another. Has age made it callous?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Well—I own this account is true, but the case was quite different. Baron Wellingrode was rewarded by his Prince with ingratitude, and the people loved him as their father, whereas Count Lohrstein—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Are you appointed his judge, or were you then the Baron's judge?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
You strike home to me.—You are right—I ought not to have connived at his escape, but I was under material obligations to him. He was my benefactor. When I was but a poor orphan, he procured me a situation in the
military academy. Through his recommendation I was made a cornet, and had he not fallen, I should long since have had a troop. Never, never can I think of that man without being affected. Gently rest his ashes!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Aside. Oh! what a blissful moment!

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I undertook to go in pursuit of him only that I might escort him to a place of safety. Sooner should my hand have withered than I would have laid it on my benefactor.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: If the memory of this man be so dear to you, give liberty to the Count for his sake.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: To the Count. Why, he it was, who ruined Baron Wellingrode.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Not I—my wife—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Immaterial. If Wellingrode has pardoned him, and taken him under his protection—

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Let him go, and throw himself upon his grave. That place of refuge will be more sacred to me than the altar.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why upon his grave? Let him throw himself into his arms Goes towards the Count with open arms. and find safety on the bosom of • reconciled enemy.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Heavens! What is this?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Presses him to his heart. Now, Brave, tear him from your old patron's arms.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: In the utmost astonishment. What! Can you—you be—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am Baron Wellingrode. The Count sinks on his knee. Welling raises him and gently seats him on a chair.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: After a pause, during which he endeavors to compose himself, presses Welling's hand between both his own, and gazes intently at him for several moments. Yes, it is he—it is my benefactor.—Alas! Have I then found him in this situation?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Content has no peculiar situation; but whether clad in ermine or the peasant's frock, dwells only with affection and domestic comfort. Good Brave, I am truly happy.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
That declaration will console me, at my dying hour. Oh thou, whose ashes I so oft have blessed, whom I a thousand times have wished back to our world that I might be
able to evince my gratitude, tell me, can old Brave do nothing for you?—I'll inform the Prince you are alive. I'll summon all your friends to appear in your behalf. Oh, how many still remember you, and bless you!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Not so, honest Brave. If I merit any recompence, bestow on me the liberty of this old man, whom the inscrutable ways of Providence have directed to my house—perhaps to try whether I was worthy of my present happiness.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Will you protect this man?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: As long as I am able.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: You have forgotten—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Every thing.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Revenge is sweet.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Forgiveness sweeter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Deeply affected. Yes. Could I not have called to mind those venerable features, I should have known you by these noble sentiments.—Feel, Count Lohrstein, feel how this man acts.—You are free. My people shall depart immediately.
sp.stage: Wipes his eye, shakes Welling's hand, and goes.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Quite abashed. My Lord—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Dear Count, I am no longer accustomed to hear that title.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Your revenge is sweet to your own sensations, but to mine, bitter.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He, who can feel thus deserves no other vengeance to be practised towards him.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: To be confounded and ashamed before an enemy is insupportable sensation.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Am I your enemy?

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: My wife's ambition robbed you of every thing.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And my heart restored to me every thing.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Your estates—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Those you mean I but inherited—those I now possess I have earned. Oh, my Lord, a tree raised by ourselves affords more pleasure than a whole wood planted by chance.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: You 〈◊〉 deprived of your rank.—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am loved here for my own sake.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: The favor of the Prince—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Favor I never aimed at. I only sought friendship in a soil, where it does not grow.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: The power of doing good.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: That dwells in every one, and may, like air, be compressed into a narrow compass. Even the beggar can purchase, with his farthing, this happy conviction.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: You will, perhaps, at last even convince me that I am your benefactor, and—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Hastily interrupting him. That you are Count. By the Almighty, that you are, for, had not your power been directed against me, I never should have gained this pleasing harmony of all my feelings, this perfect satisfaction, this peace, which neither passion nor reproach can disturb. I am healthy, in easy circumstances, and possessed of an affectionate wife, and three good children—I am never peevish, never tormented by that demon, ennui—I am familiar with nature, and surrounded by uncorrupted people. I find sincerity in every hut, affection in every eye, and peace in my own breast.—Point out to me the man at court, who, while basking in the sun-shine of favor, can say as much—Yes, Count, you are indeed my benefactor.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Is it not enough to have abashed me? Would you excite my envy too?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Share my happiness by remaining with us.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Alas! it is too late. The art of being happy must, like other arts, be learnt in youth. When old, it can no longer be comprehended.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You are mistaken. The art of being happy, consists in seriously wishing to be so.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Yes, if you could raise my first wife from the dead, if you could restore my unhappy son to me—

div.stage: PAULINA rushes breathless into the room.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Father! Father!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What now, my child? Is your mother ill?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No. Lewis—Lewis—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Scarcely able to articulate. He is dead.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: God forbid! Has he killed himself?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No—the hussars—

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: In a tone of triumph. Such are the consequences—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What is the matter, Mr. Ernorf? Speak! My poor girl cannot.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Thus it is, when all sorts of people are admitted into a family.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I beseech you, for Heaven's sake to wave your comments, and relate what has happened.

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: Well, then—Mr. Lewis, with his usual forwardness, has thought proper to attack, the hussars, who, in return, have struck off his nose and ears, and split his scull completely asunder.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Is he dead?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: He is struggling, as yet—but that will soon be over.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Ern.
sp.p: He was carried into the room, where your laborers sit. Exit. Wel. hastily. He'll not make any more verses now, but I will be so generous as to sketch an elegy for him.

div.stage: Paulina sheds not a tear, but looks around her with wild despair.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Approaching her compassionately. Good lady, who is this Lewis?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: With a convulsive smile. Don't you know him?

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Perhaps your brother?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: With heartfelt sorrow. Yes—my brother.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Compose yourself. He may still recover.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: May he? Are you a surgeon? Oh, save him!

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: No. dear lady, I am not a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Sinks on her knees before the chair. Then save him, thou, oh God!

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Looks at her with sympathy. Good father! Where is thy peace and happiness now?

div.head: ACT THE FIFTH.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Seats herself. I can no more.—Weary as I am, I can find no rest.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Wiping his forehead. A hot day this, good neighbor—understood?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Alas, Mr. Dalner! What an intermixture of joy and sorrow!

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: All's well that ends well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: They won't admit me to my Lewis.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: He must be kept quite composed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Have you seen him?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: No—nor do I wish it. I don't like even to be present when a stag is dying.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! Then you really think he will die?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I can stay no longer with the stranger.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Who sent you to him?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: My father wished it. He thought it might dissipate my anxiety, but his conduct is so strange, that he quite alarms me. He walks up and down the room, talking to himself. When I speak to him he smiles, and if he makes any reply, it is quite unintelligible.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: His misfortunes may perhaps have— Pointing to his head. Understood?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: And no one was compassionate enough to bring me any tidings of Lewis. Is he still alive?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Yes, he is.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Will he recover?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: The surgeon and your father are with him, but they will not allow any other person to enter the room.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Oh! You won't tell me—but I am sure he is dead.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: He is not indeed. A couple of wounds seldom kill a man.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: In ill-humor. The infernal scoundrels have better horses than our's.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Where have you been? You seem quite heated.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Your foresters, Mr. Dalner, and I, and a dozen of the villagers, followed the hussars as long as we could see the dust, but we couldn't keep pace with them.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Well, and suppose you had overtaken them?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Then, as I hope to be saved, they should have paid dearly for every drop of blood, which Lewis has shed.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I thank you, brother.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: And if they had wounded you in the same way?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: What a hot-headed stripling! How do you know whether Lewis was not guilty of the first provocation?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I am sure he was not.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: If he attacked them, I am sure he had good reason for it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Does nobody yet know how the quarrel arose?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: How can any body know it? Lewis is unable to speak, and the hussars have run away.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Were none of our people concerned, then?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Not one.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Well, father?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: How go matters on?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Is Lewis better?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Will he recover?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He is out of danger.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W. and Pau.
sp.p: Heaven be praised!

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I must go to him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
Hold, Frederick! The surgeon has prescribed quiet as the most effectual medicine. His wounds have been examined.
That in the head is of no consequence—the one in his arm is larger, but not dangerous. It was only the loss of blood which overpowered him, and he is come to himself again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: You know, then, what has happened?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: No. He was going to tell me, but the surgeon would not allow him to speak, and desired us to leave the room, as repose was absolutely necessary. Nobody but Mr. Rehberg remained with him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: He is not in want of any thing, I hope?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I have provided every thing necessary.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Are you sure of that, father? If you would allow me—if I might—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: In a tone of admonition. Paulina?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: You are right. It is improper.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Lewis insists on speaking to you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I will come to him, when he has slept awhile.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: He says he cannot sleep, be easy, or recover, 'till he has had some conversation with you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: If the surgeon will allow it—

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: The surgeon thinks composure of mind still more necessary than sleep, and I too am of opinion, that if his soul be wounded, you may effect more than the whole faculty.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Enough! I hasten to him.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Shrieks. Oh! There he is.

div.stage: Enter LEWIS, Pale and rather weak, with his head bound, and his arm in a sling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Runs to him, and embraces him. Lewis!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Shakes him by the hand. Brave lad!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Lewis, can you, when scarcely recovering from a swoon, thus creep up stairs again?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Oh, I am not ill—I was only stunned.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I was just coming to you.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: My impatience and anxiety have driven me hither. Allow me a few words without a witness.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Be seated, then. Go, friends. Neighbor, I know you will not take it amiss.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Not another word. Come, neighbor Rehberg.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Lewis, I have such a regard for you, that I have not thought of Louisa before. I'll away to meet her.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Oh Lewis! How pale you look!
sp.stage: Hides her face, and exit into her chamber.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Don't let him talk too much, good William, lest he should irritate his wounds.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Be not afraid, dear mother. He will heal my deepest wound.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Now, Lewis, we are alone.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Father, I am obliged to you for inestimable kindnesses, and beg to-day a greater than any of them.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You know me. Speak.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: You must have been surprised on hearing that I attacked the hussars.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I was, indeed, for I have always thought you of a peaceable disposition.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: When I left you, I intended to travel a few miles before sun-set, but my heart was so heavy, that my feet could not support me. I went to the little inn, which was full of hussars. I left them—wandered into the garden, and seated myself under an elm, where I indulged myself in a flood of tears. Ere long two of the hussars joined me. They laughed at me for my effeminacy—as they called it—but I paid no regard to them. At length they ceased their taunts, and began to converse about their own concerns—in which, alas, I was too nearly concerned.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: They spoke in opprobrious terms of my father.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Your father!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: They called him a villain, and by the Almighty that he is not.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Who is your father?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: A weak, but a good man. He was high in office—Heaven knows what has lately happened to him! He must have fled, and these hussars, as far as I can learn, are in pursuit of him.—The two I mentioned, having spoken of him in terms the most abusive, I could no longer refrain—I considered not that I alone was opposing twenty—I considered nothing but my father's honor, and struck the villain, whose language had been most opprobrious, to the earth. Of course, I immediately became the victim of my rashness.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Lewis!—Is it possible?—Who are you?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You are in search of one Count Lohrstein?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: He it is.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He is your father!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Aside. Oh God, what bliss hast thou reserved for me on this day! Aloud. Speak, worthy youth! Let me have all your confidence. Let not two fathers be too many for you. Relate to me the mysterious particulars of your fate.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p:
My first education and my heart destined me to act a happy, but not a brilliant part in the world. My mother was formed for domestic comfort, and formed me for the enjoyment of domestic comfort. She died. An ambitious deceitful woman succeeded to my father's affections. Through her, he became minister—through her I too was to make my fortune (as it is called) at court. I was married to a woman, whom I knew not, but whom I discovered, when too late, to be the Prince's mistress. Yes. Then I might have raised myself, from step to step, in splendid infamy, and bending under the load of turpitude, might have climbed to the summit of courtly favor. But, thanks to Heaven, the sentiments, which she, who now enjoys celestial bliss, had graven in my mind, could not be eradicated by my step-mother. Soon as I discovered the labyrinth, in which they had involved my inexperience, my resolution was irrevocably
formed. I fled. From a delicacy, which was, perhaps carried to too great an excess, I took nothing with me. Beg I could not—I knew not how to work, so that at last, driven by hunger and despair, I accepted the offers of the recruiting party, with which you found me.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Now, all is plain—and how do I rejoice to find it thus! How Willingly do I request your pardon for the suspicion, which to-day I could not quite suppress!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: My character must have appeared dubious to you, and alas! that alone made my separation from you so painful.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why did you not sooner discover yourself?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Could I accuse my father—or could I assist him? Even now, I would not have broken my silence, had not anxiety for his safety compelled me to do it. He is pursued and suspected to be in this neighborhood. I am, at present incapable of assisting him; for my arm is maimed, and the loss of blood has so much reduced me, that I cannot even go in search of him, to give him notice that he is pursued. Oh, I beseech you, kind, benevolent, generous man, I beseech you, send all your people through the wood, the roads, the hills, and if they find him—have compassion on his age—on his misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I engage that he shall find beneath my roof a safe retreat. But at present attend to the wounds, which reflect so much honor upon you, and quietly await the issue. Will you do this?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Quietly! Oh!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Go into my study. Throw yourself upon the couch, and sleep if you can.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Bring me some account of my father. 'Till then I cannot sleep.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Looking after him in great emotion. Indeed! — God has been pleased to place in my hands the means of rewarding thy virtue, noble youth. To release thee from bondage so unworthy of thy heart is my lot. Goes to a chamber door. Paulina!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Lewis is in my study.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Alarmed. Not ill again?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Not ill, but alone, and that he dislikes. Go, and keep him company.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Astonished. How, my father?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Have you not understood me? I wish you to keep Lewis company. Is that so difficult to you?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Oh no—I do not understand it—but I obey most willingly.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What extatic moments now await me!—Yes, good Brave, you are right: Such revenge is sweet — But they are both weak, and exausted.—How shall I prepare them for the interview? I must consult my Ann.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Unannounced, but not I hope unwelcome—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Heavens! What do I see? Zahn! My honest Zahn!

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Will your Excellency allow a faithful old servant—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Silence! Silence! No Excellency dwells here. Come into my arms, thou honest man, thou only friend, from whom misfortune has not severed me. Clasps him with ferver in his arms.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Returning his embrace with reserve. An honor—as well as a pleasure — Oh that I should live to enjoy this hour in my old age!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What, for Heaven's sake, has brought you to my peaceful retreat?

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Somewhat ceremoniously. His Serene Highness has been pleased to command—had he been pleased to appoint me one of his Privy Council, he would not have so highly honored me—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What is your business, then, dear Zahn? I see tears in your eyes.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: I humbly beg pardon—but just at this moment I cannot suppress them.
sp.stage: Turns away, and wipes his eyes.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Surveys him, and turns aside, much affected. Fifty years has he lived at court, yet has it had no influence but on his manners. Aside. I hear the old Prince is dead?

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Composing himself. Yes, it has pleased the Highest to take him home, and what I prophesied twenty-seven years ago has happened. The prayers of the poor and forsaken, whose father you always were, have been heard, and his Serene Highness restores to you all your former offices, estates, and dignities.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How could the Prince learn—

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Pardon me, my Lord. When his Highness was pleased to manifest his sentiments, I found it impossible to keep silence any longer. I therefore announced myself, obtained an audience, and reported what I knew.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Your intentions were good, but—

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: His Highness was highly delighted. "Such a man," he was pleased to observe, "is wanting both for me and my subjects. Haste, and invite him to court."

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I again appear at court!

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Yes, I, old as I am, shall have the honor of again serving in the administration of your Excellency. I own I cannot proceed with the same facility as twenty-seven years ago, but the pleasure of doing my duty under my old worthy director, will make me young again.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: No, dear Zahn. To court I shall not return. I am not disposed again to encounter the cabals of Countess Lohrstein.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: No, my Lord. The Countess has finished her cabals, and at present is a prisoner in the castle.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How! Was she not closely allied to the Prince's female friend?

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Ladies, who are allied in that way, seldom hold their post ad dies vitae. The order of the privy council was indeed issued at the instigation of the Countess Lohrstein's late daughter-in-law.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Late!—How so?

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: His Serene Highness has been pleased to declare the marriage null and void.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: On account of her having been shamefully forsaken by her husband.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Embracing him with fervor. Oh, my friend! This intelligence is more welcome to me than the restoration of my estates and rank.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: I do not exactly comprehend—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You soon will. You soon shall share with me the enjoyment of this evening.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: It is his Highness's wish that you should return with me immediately.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: No, dear Zahn, I shall not return with you.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: This most gracious invitation is written by his own hand.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Breaks the seal, and reads it. Most kind, most gracious, and I could almost say, most sincere—but I shall not go.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: I am astonished.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sit but one evening at my frugal board, and you will no longer be astonished. Draws out a small key. Look, dear Zahn, this key is rusty. Opens the closet with much difficulty. It will scarcely do its duty. Takes a packet out of the closet. Here are the insignia of the order to which I belonged—my diploma—and all the remains of my former greatness. I pledge to you my word, that this closet has not been opened during five-and-twenty years.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Your Excellency opens it to-day for the good of your country.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Can my country be so devoid of honest men, as to make this necessary? No. Virtue will appear at court, as soon as the court will respect her.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: For the good of your family—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Enough, my family shall decide the matter. 'Till then, good Zahn, I claim your secrecy.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: I know how to obey.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Let me but have time to recollect myself; occurrences have followed each other so rapidly to-day, that I feel I am appointed by Heaven to make many people happy, yet know not how to begin. Come, honest Zahn! Takes his hand. Walk into this room—we shall soon see each other again. Opens the door, and calls. Neighbor, I send another friend to you, and put him under your protection, 'till I have finished some business, which just now engages me.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Within. Understood. Come in.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Mr. Rehberg, I wish to have a little conversation with you.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Here I am.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You wish to marry my daughter Rosa, I presume?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: What a question!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: She is your's.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Mr. Welling!—Why this sudden alteration in your sentiments? I am as poor as I was!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: But I am not so pertinacious as I was.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: If you be not in earnest—this is cruel.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: If you any longer doubt it, you will hurt me.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Falls on his neck. Oh, worthy mysterious man!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: As to the mysterious part of my character, it will soon be explained. Have the goodness, my son, to assemble my whole family, and all my friends in this room immediately. You will find Paulina there. I wish to converse on a subject, which relates to us all, and on the decision of which, each shall have a vote. Takes the packet from the table and is going. Rosa meets him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Ha!—Just at the right time. Takes her hand, ads her to Rehberg, joins their hands, and embraces them. God bless you!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What does this mean?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: That Rosa is mine.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: How! — I must rub my eyes to be certain that I am not dreaming.—Have you obtained a living?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh, I don't ask on my own account, for I am really glad you are poor. I always think one can't convince a rich man, how much one loves him.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Whom do you call a rich man? Oh, I am rich indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Rosa, remember that you are still a great distance from the altar.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: No. We have reached it, if your blessing be our conductor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: How am I to understand this?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My father has consented.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: And if his parental blessing be echoed from your lips—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: With all my heart—although I do not comprehend—

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: He will soon be here again. My transport had almost made me forget what he desired. All, who are united to him by affection or by friendship are to assemble in this room. Goes to the door of the dining-room. Mr. Dalner—sir—we request your company here.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Mother, this gentleman is one of my father's friends.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: You are welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Mr. Zahn, this is the lady of the house.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Accept, madam, the assurances of my respect and—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: No more, I beg sir. You are among • imple country people.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Who has in the mean time opened the door of the study. By order of your father, dear Paulina, I invite you hither—as well as Lewis, if strength with allow it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Astonished. How, Paulina!—You in that room!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: My •• ther himself sent me to keep Lewis company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Well, for the first time in my life I cannot discover the motives for your father's conduct.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Attentively observing Lewis —aside. I should know that young man.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Aside. Heavens! What can this man want here?

div.stage: Enter WELLING, With a star upon his coat, and the ribband of the order. He holds in his hand the Prince's letter. On his appearance all speak confusedly among each other.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Dear husband, what means this?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Father, is it you?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Neighbor, are we going to have a masquerade?

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: I suspect a secret, here.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Brother, what is all this?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Don't you see I am as much astonished as yourself?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Aside. That is the order to which my father belonged.

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Aside. I alone have the key to this enigma.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You seem as if you think me little better than a lunatic?—Be patient. In one moment the mystery will be solved—but let me not be interrupted. Lewis, how do you feel? Have you sufficient strength to receive from me a present, which your filial affection has obtained from fate?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Starts. Father, I do not comprehend you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Has your heart no presages?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: With tremulous utterance. Were it so—if my heart deceive me not—oh, do not keep me in suspence.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Paulina, go for our guest.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: In great agitation. Guest!—And these mysterious words—may I accompany Paulina?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Stay Where you are. I have said enough. Doubt—hope—think of your wounds—and moderate your rapture. Lewis breathes with difficulty and rivets his eye upon the door, no longer observing what passes around him. Welling points to Rehberg. I have given this man my promise, dear wife, that he shall have Rosa.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I could scarcely believe it for ••• ording to our conversation yesterday—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He was first to obtain a benefice—and he has obtained one. My son, I congratulate you on your appointment to the living of Birkendorf.

sp.speaker: Reh.
sp.p: Quite astonished. Birkendorf!—Dear sir—how can you—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Be so forward as to promise what—

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Smiling. The gentleman may be at ease.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: But explain to us—

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: In truth, neighbor—

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Distracted with anxiety. I hear footsteps.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Make room for him, children. He has been long enough deprived of his father.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: His father!

div.stage: Lewis stands at a short distance from the Count, and in great agitation stretches out the arm which is at liberty.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Violently terrified. What phantom do I behold?—Wert thou slain, bloody form, and comest thou to demand revenge?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Kneeling. Forgive your son.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Forgive!—I, thee!—Oh, if I be not wrong in thinking thee a spirit—come into my arms. Lewis rushes into his arms. —What is this?—I again feel a heart beating against mine—I feel a warm tear upon my cheek.—Am I, then, still beloved by any one on earth? Lewis, dost thou still love me?

div.stage: Lewis kneels, and covers his father's hand with tears and kisses.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Spare him, my Lord. That he loves you these wounds declare, which he received to-day in defence of your honor.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: And thou kneel'st to me!—Let me—let me kneel.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Hinders it, and presses him with fervor to his heart. Father!

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: What have I lost? I hear a voice, which calls me father.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Wealth and dignity divided us—poverty and lowliness restore us to each other.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Where was I? What apathy had crept around my heart?—Forgive me, Lewis, for thy mother's sake.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I have not been in distress—thanks to this worthy man, who received me as his son.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: How! Has he been thy benefactor too?—Could you consider the son of your enemy as your own son?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: His enemy!

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: I guess how this is.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Oh my Lord!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Lord!

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: What revenge is this!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The only revenge which becomes me.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: What means this?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My friends, it is time that I solve this enigma. Will you pardon me, my dearest Ann, if I have concealed this only secret from you? You will, I am certain, when I tell you I was obliged to promise inviolable secrecy to your father on his death-bed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Confused and astonished. Are you really a Lord, then?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am Baron Wellingrode, formerly the favorite of a Prince and not happy—now an honest farmer, and the happiest man on earth. All shew signs of astonishment. This letter from a good Prince restores to me my rank, estates, and former office. This man is come to conduct me to court.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W. Fre. Pau. and Ros.
sp.p: Alarmed. To court!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The hand, which has here so long held the plough has forgotten how to guide the rudder of a state. Nevertheless, if you, my dear wife and children, think this alteration in our fortunes enviable, I will comply with your wishes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Oh no!

sp.speaker: Fre. Pau. and Ros.
sp.p: No, no!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Consider well. What thousands sigh for, in vain, is offered you by chance.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: What do we want?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: We are accustomed to our present situation.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What can we do at court?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You may hereafter repent—

sp.speaker: Fre. Pau. and Ros.
sp.p: Never! Never!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Is this your firm desire?

sp.speaker: Fre. Pau. and Ros.
sp.p: It is! It is!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Opens his arms. Come, then, to my heart.
sp.stage: The children approach with a degree of timidity.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What now? Are you afraid of me?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Oh no—but the star—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: The ribband—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: You are grown a Baron so suddenly—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My dear Ann, you seem to keep at a distance, too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: My dear William, I am sorry to do it—but you appear almost a stranger to me—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And shall I return to a situation, which causes a distance between me and my family? Shall I wear a star, which withholds my wife and children from my bosom. Throws the ribband away with violence. Take it—take it—release me from this gew-gaw.

div.stage: The children run to him with delight, take the star from his breast, and lay it aside with the ribband.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: There!—Now you are our father again.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Now we know you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Now we love you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And you, good Ann?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Thus you offered me your hand twenty-five years ago.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You see, dear Zahn—

sp.speaker: Zah.
sp.p: Wiping his eyes. I do, and wish his Serene Highness had seen it also.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To court I'll go, but only to thank the Prince, and petition for the pardon of this man.

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: You destroy me.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How? By acting a self-interested part? I shall only be promoting the happiness of our son.—Lewis, the Prince has declared your marriage void.
sp.stage: Lewis gazes at him in silent astonishment.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Count, the young people like each other. Will you seal our reconciliation?

sp.speaker: Loh.
sp.p: Will I! How can you ask? Lewis clasps Paulina with ardor in his arms. Oh God!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Giving her hand to Rehberg. Now we are all happy.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Much affected. All.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And through me.—My children I have doubled, and I have found a brother.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Two brothers, neighbor—understood?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come then to me, all. Come into the arms of the happiest man on earth. Are you still afraid of me? No star now hides my heart. Let me press you all to it.

div.stage: Mrs. Welling sinks on his bosom, while the surrounding children hang on him and caress him.
